div.p: Learn more about how COVID-19 is affecting New Ulm Public Schools and our plans to continue providing instruction to our students.

div.class: et_pb_with_border et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_2 et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light

p.span: We are entering a new phase of education while schools are closed. Our staff is prepared to assist families and students during distance learning education. Each building has a distance learning plan that will meet what families and students are able to accomplish. We understand the stress and strain on families during these times and our staff will work with you. Please reach out to your students school with any questions you may have.

div.p: During this time of uncertainty, we all need to roll up our sleeves and work together as a community and region. The school is a strong and willing community partner and will do what we can to help our parents and communities in these difficult times. We have designed this resource page to convey updated information on what we are doing for programming and to answer your questions.

a.download: MDE Governor Executive Order Closing Schools.pdf

span.span: MDE Governor Executive Order Closing Schools

a.download: MDE Governor Executive Order Extending Distance Learning.pdf

span.span: MDE Governor Executive Order Extending Distance Learning

div.class: et_pb_with_border et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_8 et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light

div.p: Distance Learning goes into effect on March 30. Please use the links below to learn how each building will be providing educational services to your child during this time.

li.a: WLC Distance Learning Guidance for Students and Parents
Jefferson Distance Learning Letter to Parents
NUMS Distance Learning Guidance for Students and Parents

div.class: et_pb_with_border et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_10 et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light

div.p: In this section we will provide information pertaining to child care, meals, and other services or programming that may be available during this unique time.

The intent of our parent survey was to plan for daycare of parents who work in the healthcare field, or who are first responders – as identified by the state of MN. We will start our plans with providing support for those identified as Tier I emergency workers. Once we have our plan up and running, we will work on plans to include Tier II essential workers, if possible. We are sorry that we can’t take more, but we have limited resources as we try to spread out the students to be safe. Here is the plan for daycare in our schools. The hours will be from 7:30 am – 3:30 pm daily.

ul.li: Pre-K and Kindergarten Students report to WLC, using the main entrance
Grades 1 and 2 report to Jefferson and use the main entrance
Grades 3-5 report to New Ulm Middle School and use the main entrance

div.p: We are asking parents to have their student bring along a snack, Pre-K, and Kindergarten students need to bring a blanket and an extra set of clothes. All students in the daycare program will receive breakfast and a cold lunch.

All meals are free of charge and include a meat sandwich, fruit, vegetable and milk for lunch. Students/parents will also receive the breakfast meal at the lunch pickup times. If you did not sign up for the meal program, please contact Teri Jespersen at 507-233-6186. Specific details can be found in our Food Delivery Letter.

ul.li: Comcast Internet Essentials (free for 60 days to qualifying households)
T-Mobile (all legacy plans now have unlimited data for 60 days from March 13)
Verizon (15GB of additional data for most customers from March 25 and April 30)
Xfinity wifi hotspots (free to all users until further notice)

div.class: et_pb_with_border et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_12 et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light

div.p: Frequently asked questions will be added to this section. If you have unanswered questions, please submit them using the the button below.

div.h5: Who are Tier 1 and Tier 2 Workers

div.p: Please review the Care for Children of Families of Emergency Workers document to determine if you are a Tier 1 or Tier 2 worker.

div.h5: Will students need to make up the time they were off during distance Learning planning?

div.p: No, students will not need to make up the time they were off during distance learning planning.

Each school site will have office hours from 7:30 AM – 3:30 PM daily while the schools are closed by the Governor’s Executive Order. Please contact the school office to coordinate any meeting requests, or to pick-up materials for your student.

div.h5: At Home Learning Resources for Students

div.p: We encourage parents/guardians to spend time with their student over the next ten days to keep them fresh with academic work. Things like math flash cards, reading books, playing cards, exercising outside, art projects and spelling lists can provide opportunities to continue to learn while at home. We have gathered online resources that can help as well:

ul.li: Storyboard Online: Storytellers reading books out loud. Each video includes an activity guide with lessons for K-5 students to do at home. (K-5)
Scholastic Learn at Home: Every day includes four separate learning experiences, each built around a thrilling, meaningful story or video. (PreK – Grades 6+)
ABCmouse: Currently offering a free subscription to those affected by COVID-19 schools closures with new Member Code: AOFLUNICEF. (PreK-2)

Spelling City: Activities to expand knowledge of vocabulary words and reading comprehension. They are offering FREE access for the rest of the school year. Enter code: VSCFree90 upon registration on their website & you’ll immediately have access. (K-8th)

Newsela: A database of current events stories tailor-made for classroom use. Currently used by NUMS students. Classroom teachers may need to share an access code with students so they can log in from home.

IXL: Math & language arts practice website. It has unlimited questions on thousands of math topics and a comprehensive reporting system. Currently used by many NUPS students already – they are offering a totally free 90 days via our link. (K-12)
BrainPop: Online lessons covering a variety of subjects. (K-12)
Mystery Science: They have pulled their most popular science lessons and are offering them for anyone to use for free. No account or login is needed. (K-5)

KhanAcademy: Khan Academy offers exercises, quizzes, and tests so students can practice and master skills, as well as instructional videos to help students learn or review material. All accounts are free. (K-8)
MathHelp: Online math courses with video instruction and interactive practice for middle school, high school, developmental college math, and standardized test prep. (K-12)
Ck12: Access to affordable, high-quality, and open educational materials for all subjects. Great for high school students. (K-12)
